Cross-Layer Optimization of MIMO-Based Mesh Networks with Gaussian Vector Broadcast Channels

Jia Liu and Y. Thomas Hou The Bradley Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering
Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, Blacksburg, VA 24061
Email: {kevinlau, thou}@vt.edu
Abstract

MIMO technology is one of the most significant advances in the past decade to increase channel capacity and has a great potential to improve network capacity for mesh networks. In a MIMO-based mesh network, the links outgoing from each node sharing the common communication spectrum can be modeled as a Gaussian vector broadcast channel. Recently, researchers showed that ‚Äúdirty paper coding‚Äù (DPC) is the optimal transmission strategy for Gaussian vector broadcast channels. So far, there has been little study on how this fundamental result will impact the cross-layer design for MIMO-based mesh networks. To fill this gap, we consider the problem of jointly optimizing DPC power allocation in the link layer at each node and multihop/multipath routing in a MIMO-based mesh networks. It turns out that this optimization problem is a very challenging non-convex problem. To address this difficulty, we transform the original problem to an equivalent problem by exploiting the channel duality. For the transformed problem, we develop an efficient solution procedure that integrates Lagrangian dual decomposition method, conjugate gradient projection method based on matrix differential calculus, cutting-plane method, and subgradient method. In our numerical example, it is shown that we can achieve a network performance gain of 34.4%percent34.434.4\% by using DPC.

I Introduction

Since Telatar‚Äôs [1] and Foschini‚Äôs [2] pioneering works predicting the potential of high spectral efficiency provided by multiple antenna systems, the last decade has witnessed a soar of research activity on Multiple-Input Multiple-Output (MIMO) technologies. The benefits of substantial improvements in wireless link capacity at no cost of additional spectrum and power have quickly positioned MIMO as one of the breakthrough technologies in modern wireless communications, rendering it as an enabling technology for next generation wireless networks. However, applying MIMO in wireless mesh networks (WMNs) is not a trivial technical extension. With the increased number of antennas at each node, interference is likely to become stronger if power level at each node, power allocation to each antenna element, and routing are not managed wisely. As a result, cross-layer design is necessary for MIMO-based WMNs.

In a MIMO-based WMN, the set of outgoing links from a node sharing a common communication spectrum can be modeled as a nondegraded Gaussian vector broadcast channel, for which the capacity region is notoriously hard to analyze [3]. In the networking literature, most works considering links sharing a common communication spectrum are concerned with how to allocate frequency sub-bands/time-slots and schedule transmissions to efficiently share the common communication spectrum. As an example, Fig.¬†1(a) shows a simple broadcast channel where there are three uncoordinated users and a single transmitting node. Suppose that messages xùë•x, yùë¶y, and zùëßz need to be delivered to user 1, user 2, and user 3, respectively. Also, suppose that the received signals subject to ambient noise are x^^ùë•\hat{x}, y^^ùë¶\hat{y}, and z^^ùëß\hat{z}, and the decoding functions are f1‚Äã(‚ãÖ)subscriptùëì1‚ãÖf_{1}(\cdot), f2‚Äã(‚ãÖ)subscriptùëì2‚ãÖf_{2}(\cdot), and f3‚Äã(‚ãÖ)subscriptùëì3‚ãÖf_{3}(\cdot), respectively. The conventional strategy is to divide a unit time frame into three time slots (or divide a unit band into three sub-bands) œÑ1subscriptùúè1\tau_{1}, œÑ2subscriptùúè2\tau_{2}, and œÑ3subscriptùúè3\tau_{3}, and then find the optimal scheduling for transmissions to users 1, 2 and 3, accordingly. The major benefit of this strategy is that interference can be eliminated.

Although the time or frequency division schemes are simple and effective, they are not necessarily the smartest strategy. In fact, Cover had shown in his classical paper [4] that the transmission scheme jointly encoding all receivers‚Äô information at the transmitter can do strictly better in broadcast channels. However, the capacity achieving transmission signaling scheme for general nondegraded Gaussian vector broadcast channels is very difficult to determine and has become one of the most basic questions in network information theory [3]. Very recently, significant progress has been made in this area. Most notably, Weigarten et. al. finally proved the long-open conjecture that the ‚Äúdirty paper coding‚Äù strategy (DPC) [5] is the optimal transmission scheme for Gaussian vector broadcast channels [6] in the sense that the DPC rate region ùíûDPCsubscriptùíûDPC\mathcal{C}_{\mathrm{DPC}} of a broadcast channel is equal to the broadcast channel‚Äôs capacity region ùíûBCsubscriptùíûBC\mathcal{C}_{\mathrm{BC}}, i.e., ùíûBC=ùíûDPCsubscriptùíûBCsubscriptùíûDPC\mathcal{C}_{\mathrm{BC}}=\mathcal{C}_{\mathrm{DPC}}. However, this fundamental result is still not adequately exposed to the networking research community. So far, how to exploit DPC‚Äôs benefits in the cross-layer design for wireless mesh networks has not yet been studied in the literature. The main objective of this study is to fill this gap and to obtain a rigorous and systematic understanding of the impact of applying DPC to the cross-layer optimization for MIMO-based mesh networks.

To begin with, it is beneficial to introduce the basic idea of DPC, which turns out to be very simple. For the same 3-user example, consider the following strategy as shown in Fig.¬†1(b). We first jointly encode the messages for all the users in a certain order and then broadcast the resulting codeword simultaneously. Suppose that we pick user 1 to be encoded first, then followed by user 2, and finally user 3. We choose the codeword xùë•x for user 1 as before. Then, the interference seen by user 2 due to user 1 (denoted by x^2subscript^ùë•2\hat{x}_{2}) is known at the transmitter. So, the transmitter can subtract the interference and encode user 2 as y‚Ä≤=y‚àíx^2superscriptùë¶‚Ä≤ùë¶subscript^ùë•2y^{\prime}=y-\hat{x}_{2} rather than yùë¶y itself. As a result, user 2 does not see any interference from the signal intended for user 1. Likewise, after encoding user 2, the interferences seen by user 3 due to user 1 and 2 (denoted by x^3subscript^ùë•3\hat{x}_{3} and y^3subscript^ùë¶3\hat{y}_{3}) are known at the transmitter. Then, the transmitter can subtract the interferences and encode user 3 as z‚Ä≤=z‚àíx^3‚àíy^3superscriptùëß‚Ä≤ùëßsubscript^ùë•3subscript^ùë¶3z^{\prime}=z-\hat{x}_{3}-\hat{y}_{3} rather than zùëßz itself. Therefore, user 3 does not see any interferences from the signals intended for user 1 and 2. In the end, the transmitter adds all the codewords together and broadcasts the sum to all users simultaneously. As a result, it is easy to see from Fig.¬†1(b) that the received signal at user 1 is x^+y^1+z^1^ùë•subscript^ùë¶1subscript^ùëß1\hat{x}+\hat{y}_{1}+\hat{z}_{1}, i.e., user 1 will experience the interference from the signals intended for users 2 and 3; the received signal at user 2 is y^+z^2^ùë¶subscript^ùëß2\hat{y}+\hat{z}_{2}, i.e., user 2 only experiences the interference from the signal intended for user 3; and finally, the received signal at user 3 is z^^ùëß\hat{z}, i.e., user 3 does not experience any interference. This process operates like writing on a dirty paper, hence the name. Although counterintuitive, the capacity region of DPC that allows interference is strictly larger than those of time or frequency division schemes.

After understanding what DPC is, one may ask two very natural and interesting questions:

  1. 1.

    How will the enlarged capacity region at each node due to DPC impact the network performance in the upper layers?

  2. 2.

    Are there any new challenges if DPC is employed in a MIMO-based networking environment?

Notice that, when DPC is employed, the encoding order plays a critical role. For a KùêæK-user broadcast channel, there exists K!ùêæK! permutations. Also, since DPC allows interference among the users, power allocation among different users along with the encoding order has a significant impact on the system performance. As we show later, the DPC link rates in a broadcast channel are non-connvex functions. Thus, even the optimization for a single KùêæK-user Gaussian vector broadcast channel is a very challenging combinatorial non-convex problem, not to mention the cross-layer design in a networking environment with multiple broadcast channels.

In this paper, we aim to solve the problem of jointly optimizing DPC per-antenna power allocation at each node in the link layer and multihop/multipath routing in a MIMO-based WMN. Our contributions are three-fold. First, this paper is the first work that studies the impacts of applying DPC to the cross-layer design for MIMO-based WMNs. In our numerical example, it is shown that we can achieve a network performance gain of 34.4%percent34.434.4\% by using DPC in MIMO-based WMNs. Also, since the traditional single-antenna systems can be viewed as a special case of MIMO systems, the findings and results in this paper are also applicable to conventional WMNs with single-antenna. Second, to address the non-convex difficulty, we transform the original problem to an equivalent problem under the dual MIMO multiple access channel (MIMO-MAC) and show that the transformed problem is convex with respect to the input covariance matrices. We simplify the maximum weighted sum rate problem for the dual MIMO-MAC such that enumerating different encoding order is unnecessary, thus paving the way to efficiently solve the link layer subproblem in Lagrangian dual decomposition. Last, for the transformed problem, we develop an efficient solution procedure that integrates Lagrangian dual decomposition method, conjugate gradient projection method based on matrix differential calculus, cutting-plane method, and subgradient method.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. In Section¬†II, we discuss the network model and problem formulation. Section¬†III discusses how to reformulate the non-connvex original problem by exploiting channel duality. In Section¬†IV, we introduce the key components for solving the challenging link layer subproblem in the Lagrangian decomposition. Numerical results are provided in Section¬†V to illustrate the efficacy of our proposed solution procedure and to study the network performance gain by using DPC. Section¬†VI reviews related work and Section¬†VII concludes this paper.

For a real vector ùêØùêØ\mathbf{v} and a real matrix ùêÄùêÄ\mathbf{A}, ùêØ‚â•ùüéùêØ0\mathbf{v}\geq\mathbf{0} and ùêÄ‚â•ùüéùêÄ0\mathbf{A}\geq\mathbf{0} mean that all entries in ùêØùêØ\mathbf{v} and ùêÄùêÄ\mathbf{A} are nonnegative, respectively. II-A Network Layer

In this paper, the topology of a MIMO-based wireless mesh network is represented by a directed graph, denoted by ùí¢={ùí©,‚Ñí}ùí¢ùí©‚Ñí\mathcal{G}=\{\mathcal{N},\mathcal{L}\}, where ùí©ùí©\mathcal{N} and ‚Ñí‚Ñí\mathcal{L} are the set of nodes and all possible MIMO-based links, respectively. By saying ‚Äúpossible‚Äù we mean the distance between a pair of nodes is less than or equal to the maximum transmission range Dmaxsubscriptùê∑D_{\max}, i.e., ‚Ñí={(i,j):Di‚Äãj‚â§Dmax,i,j‚ààùí©,i‚â†j}‚Ñíconditional-setùëñùëóformulae-sequencesubscriptùê∑ùëñùëósubscriptùê∑ùëñformulae-sequenceùëóùí©ùëñùëó\mathcal{L}=\{(i,j):D_{ij}\leq D_{\max},\,i,j\in\mathcal{N},i\neq j\}, where Di‚Äãjsubscriptùê∑ùëñùëóD_{ij} represents the distance between node iùëñi and node jùëój. Dmaxsubscriptùê∑D_{\max} can be determined by a node‚Äôs maximum transmission power. We assume that ùí¢ùí¢\mathcal{G} is always connected. Suppose that the cardinalities of the sets ùí©ùí©\mathcal{N} and ‚Ñí‚Ñí\mathcal{L} are |ùí©|=Nùí©ùëÅ|\mathcal{N}|=N and |‚Ñí|=L‚Ñíùêø|\mathcal{L}|=L, respectively. For convenience, we index the links numerically (e.g., link 1,2,‚Ä¶,L12‚Ä¶ùêø1,2,\ldots,L) rather than using node pairs (i,j)ùëñùëó(i,j).

(1)

We define ùí™‚Äã(n)ùí™ùëõ\mathcal{O}\left(n\right) and ‚Ñê‚Äã(n)‚Ñêùëõ\mathcal{I}\left(n\right) as the sets of links that are outgoing from and incoming to node nùëõn, respectively. We use a multicommodity flow model for the routing of data packets across the network. In this model, several nodes send different data to their corresponding destinations, possibly through multipath and multihop routing. We assume that the flow conservation law at each node is satisfied, i.e., the network is a flow-balanced system.

Suppose that there are FùêπF sessions in total in the network, representing FùêπF different commodities. II-B Channel Capacity of a MIMO Link

In this section, we first briefly introduce some background of MIMO. We use a matrix ùêál‚àà‚ÑÇnr√óntsubscriptùêáùëôsuperscript‚ÑÇsubscriptùëõùëüsubscriptùëõùë°\mathbf{H}_{l}\in\mathbb{C}^{n_{r}\times n_{t}} to represent the MIMO channel gain matrix from the transmitting node to the receiving node of link lùëôl, where ntsubscriptùëõùë°n_{t} and nrsubscriptùëõùëün_{r} are the numbers of transmitting and receiving antenna elements of each node, respectively. ùêálsubscriptùêáùëô\mathbf{H}_{l} captures the effect of the scattering environment between the transmitter and the receiver of link lùëôl. In an additive white Gaussian noise (AWGN) channel, the received complex base-band signal vector for a MIMO link lùëôl with ntsubscriptùëõùë°n_{t} transmitting antennas and nrsubscriptùëõùëün_{r} receiving antennas is given by

ùê≤l=œÅl‚Äãùêál‚Äãùê±l+ùêßl.subscriptùê≤ùëôsubscriptùúåùëôsubscriptùêáùëôsubscriptùê±ùëôsubscriptùêßùëô\mathbf{y}_{l}=\sqrt{\rho_{l}}\mathbf{H}_{l}\mathbf{x}_{l}+\mathbf{n}_{l}. (6)

where ùê≤lsubscriptùê≤ùëô\mathbf{y}_{l} and ùê±lsubscriptùê±ùëô\mathbf{x}_{l} represent the received and transmitted signal vector; ùêßlsubscriptùêßùëô\mathbf{n}_{l} is the normalized additive white Gaussian noise vector; œÅlsubscriptùúåùëô\rho_{l} captures the path-loss effect, which is usually modeled as œÅl=G‚ãÖDl‚àíŒ±subscriptùúåùëô‚ãÖùê∫superscriptsubscriptùê∑ùëôùõº\rho_{l}=G\cdot D_{l}^{-\alpha}, where Gùê∫G is some system specific constant, Dlsubscriptùê∑ùëôD_{l} denotes the distance between the transmitting node and the receiving node of link lùëôl, and Œ±ùõº\alpha denotes the path loss exponent. Let matrix ùêêlsubscriptùêêùëô\mathbf{Q}_{l} represent the covariance matrix of a zero-mean Gaussian input symbol vector ùê±lsubscriptùê±ùëô\mathbf{x}_{l} at link lùëôl, i.e., ùêêl=ùîº‚Äã{ùê±l‚ãÖùê±l‚Ä†}subscriptùêêùëôùîº‚ãÖsubscriptùê±ùëôsuperscriptsubscriptùê±ùëô‚Ä†\mathbf{Q}_{l}=\mathbb{E}\left\{\mathbf{x}_{l}\cdot\mathbf{x}_{l}^{{\dagger}}\right\}. This implies that ùêêlsubscriptùêêùëô\mathbf{Q}_{l} is Hermitian and ùêêl‚™∞0succeeds-or-equalssubscriptùêêùëô0\mathbf{Q}_{l}\succeq 0. Physically, ùêêlsubscriptùêêùëô\mathbf{Q}_{l} represents the power allocation in different antenna elements in link lùëôl‚Äôs transmitter and the correlation between each pair of the transmit and receive antenna elements. Tr‚Äã{ùêêl}Trsubscriptùêêùëô\mathrm{Tr}\{\mathbf{Q}_{l}\} is the total transmission power at the transmitter of link lùëôl. The capacity of a MIMO link lùëôl in an AWGN channel with a unit bandwidth can be computed as

Rl‚Äã(ùêêl)=log2‚Å°|ùêà+œÅl‚Äãùêál‚Äãùêêl‚Äãùêál‚Ä†|,subscriptùëÖùëôsubscriptùêêùëôsubscript2ùêàsubscriptùúåùëôsubscriptùêáùëôsubscriptùêêùëôsuperscriptsubscriptùêáùëô‚Ä†\displaystyle R_{l}(\mathbf{Q}_{l})=\log_{2}\left|\mathbf{I}+\rho_{l}\mathbf{H}_{l}\mathbf{Q}_{l}\mathbf{H}_{l}^{{\dagger}}\right|, (7)

It can be seen that different power allocations to the antennas will have different impacts on the link capacity. Therefore, the optimal input covariance matrix ùêêl‚àósuperscriptsubscriptùêêùëô\mathbf{Q}_{l}^{*} needs to be determined. In a single link environment, the optimal input covariance matrix can be computed by water-filling the total power over the eigenmodes (signaling direction) of the MIMO channel matrix [1]. However, in a networking environment, finding the optimal input covariance matrices is a substantially more challenging task. Determining the optimal input covariance matrices is one of the major goals in our cross-layer optimization.

II-C MIMO-BC Link Layer

A communication system where a single transmitter sends independent information to multiple uncoordinated receivers is referred to as a broadcast channel. If the channel gain of each link in the broadcast channel is a matrix and the noise to each link is a Gaussian random vector, the channel is termed ‚ÄúGaussian vector broadcast channel‚Äù. Fig.¬†2 illustrates a KùêæK-user Gaussian vector broadcast channel, where independent messages W1,‚Ä¶,WKsubscriptùëä1‚Ä¶subscriptùëäùêæW_{1},\ldots,W_{K} are jointly encoded by the transmitter, and the receivers are trying to decode W1,‚Ä¶,WKsubscriptùëä1‚Ä¶subscriptùëäùêæW_{1},\ldots,W_{K}, respectively. A (n,2n‚ÄãR1,‚Ä¶,2n‚ÄãRK)B‚ÄãCsubscriptùëõsuperscript2ùëõsubscriptùëÖ1‚Ä¶superscript2ùëõsubscriptùëÖùêæùêµùê∂(n,2^{nR_{1}},\ldots,2^{nR_{K}})_{BC} codebook for a broadcast channel consists of an encoding function ùê±n‚Äã(W1,‚Ä¶,WK)superscriptùê±ùëõsubscriptùëä1‚Ä¶subscriptùëäùêæ\mathbf{x}^{n}(W_{1},\ldots,W_{K}) where Wi‚àà{1,‚Ä¶,2n‚ÄãRi}subscriptùëäùëñ1‚Ä¶superscript2ùëõsubscriptùëÖùëñW_{i}\in\{1,\ldots,2^{nR_{i}}\}, i=1,2,‚Ä¶,Kùëñ12‚Ä¶ùêæi=1,2,\ldots,K. The decoding function of receiver iùëñi is W^i‚Äã(ùê≤in)subscript^ùëäùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùê≤ùëñùëõ\hat{W}_{i}(\mathbf{y}_{i}^{n}) . An error occurs when W^i‚â†Wisubscript^ùëäùëñsubscriptùëäùëñ\hat{W}_{i}\neq W_{i}. A rate vector ùêë=[R1,‚Ä¶,RK]TùêësuperscriptsubscriptùëÖ1‚Ä¶subscriptùëÖùêæùëá\mathbf{R}=[R_{1},\ldots,R_{K}]^{T} is said to be achievable if there exists a sequence of (n,2n‚ÄãR1,‚Ä¶,2n‚ÄãRK)BCsubscriptùëõsuperscript2ùëõsubscriptùëÖ1‚Ä¶superscript2ùëõsubscriptùëÖùêæBC(n,2^{nR_{1}},\ldots,2^{nR_{K}})_{\mathrm{BC}} codebooks for which the average probability of error Pe‚Üí0‚ÜísubscriptùëÉùëí0P_{e}\rightarrow 0 as the code length n‚Üí‚àû‚Üíùëõn\rightarrow\infty. The capacity region of a broadcast channel is defined as the union of all achievable rate vectors [3]. Gaussian vector broadcast channel can be used to model many different types of systems [3]. Due to the close relationship between Gaussian vector broadcast channel and MIMO, we will call the Gaussian vector broadcast channel in the MIMO case as MIMO-BC throughout the rest of this paper.

For clarity, we use ùö™isubscriptùö™ùëñ\mathbf{\Gamma}_{i} to specifically denote the input covariance matrix of link iùëñi in a MIMO-BC, and ùêêjsubscriptùêêùëó\mathbf{Q}_{j} to denote an input covariance matrix in other types of MIMO channels. From the encoding process of DPC, the achievable rate in DPC scheme can be computed as follows:

II-D Problem Formulation

In this paper, we aim to solve the problem of jointly optimizing DPC per-antenna power allocation at each node in the link layer and multihop/multipath routing in a MIMO-based WMN. Suppose that each node in the network has been assigned a certain (possibly reused) frequency band that will not cause interference to any other node in the network. Also, the incoming and outgoing bands of each node are non-overlapping such that each node can transmit and receive simultaneously. How to perform channel assignments is a huge research topic on its own merits, and there are a vast amount of literature that discuss channel assignment problems. Thus, in this paper, we focus on how to jointly optimize routing in the network layer and the DPC power allocation in the link layer for each node when a channel assignment is given. We adopt the well-known proportional fairness utility function, i.e., ln‚Å°(sf)subscriptùë†ùëì\ln(s_{f}) for flow fùëìf. In CRPA, we wish to maximize the sum of all utility functions. In the link layer, since the total transmit power of each node is subject to a maximum power constraint, we have ‚àël‚ààùí™‚Äã(n)Tr‚Äã{ùö™l}‚â§Pmax(n)subscriptùëôùí™ùëõTrsubscriptùö™ùëôsuperscriptsubscriptùëÉùëõ\sum_{l\in\mathcal{O}\left(n\right)}\mathrm{Tr}\{\mathbf{\Gamma}_{l}\}\leq P_{\max}^{(n)}, 1‚â§n‚â§N1ùëõùëÅ1\leq n\leq N, where Pmax(n)superscriptsubscriptùëÉùëõP_{\max}^{(n)} represents the maximum transmit power of node nùëõn. Since the total amount of flow in each link lùëôl cannot exceed its capacity limit, we must have ‚àëf=1Ftl(f)‚â§Rl‚Äã(ùö™)superscriptsubscriptùëì1ùêπsuperscriptsubscriptùë°ùëôùëìsubscriptùëÖùëôùö™\sum_{f=1}^{F}t_{l}^{(f)}\leq R_{l}(\mathbf{\Gamma}), 1‚â§l‚â§L1ùëôùêø1\leq l\leq L. This can be further compactly written using matrix-vector notations as ‚ü®ùüè,ùêìT‚Äãùêûl‚ü©‚â§Rl‚Äã(ùö™)1superscriptùêìùëásubscriptùêûùëôsubscriptùëÖùëôùö™\langle\mathbf{1},\mathbf{T}^{T}\mathbf{e}_{l}\rangle\leq R_{l}(\mathbf{\Gamma}), 1‚â§l‚â§L1ùëôùêø1\leq l\leq L. Coupling the network layer model in Section¬†II-A and MIMO-BC link layer model in Section¬†II-C, we have the problem formulation for CRPA as in (9).

III Reformulation of CRPA

As we pointed out earlier, the DPC rate equation in (8) is neither a concave nor a convex function of the input covariance matrices. As a result, the cross-layer optimization problem in (9) is a non-convex optimization problem, which is very hard to solve numerically, let alone analytically. However, in the following, we will show that (9) can be reformulated as an equivalent convex optimization problem by projecting all the MIMO-BC channels onto their dual MIMO multiple-access channels (MIMO-MAC). We first provide some background of Gaussian vector multiple access channels and the channel duality between MIMO-BC and MIMO-MAC.

III-A MIMO-MAC Channel Model

A communication system where multiple uncoordinated transmitters send independent information to a single receiver is referred to as a multiple access channel. If the channel gain of each link in the multiple access channel is a matrix and the noise is a Gaussian random vector, the channel is termed ‚ÄúGaussian vector multiple access channel‚Äù. Fig.¬†3 illustrates a KùêæK-user Gaussian vector multiple access channel, where independent messages W1,‚Ä¶,WKsubscriptùëä1‚Ä¶subscriptùëäùêæW_{1},\ldots,W_{K}, are encoded by transmitters 1 to KùêæK, respectively, and the receiver is trying to decode W1,‚Ä¶,WKsubscriptùëä1‚Ä¶subscriptùëäùêæW_{1},\ldots,W_{K}. A (n,2n‚ÄãR1,‚Ä¶,2n‚ÄãRK)MACsubscriptùëõsuperscript2ùëõsubscriptùëÖ1‚Ä¶superscript2ùëõsubscriptùëÖùêæMAC(n,2^{nR_{1}},\ldots,2^{nR_{K}})_{\mathrm{MAC}} codebook for a multiple access channel consists of encoding functions ùê±1n‚Äã(W1),‚Ä¶,ùê±Kn‚Äã(WK)superscriptsubscriptùê±1ùëõsubscriptùëä1‚Ä¶superscriptsubscriptùê±ùêæùëõsubscriptùëäùêæ\mathbf{x}_{1}^{n}(W_{1}),\ldots,\mathbf{x}_{K}^{n}(W_{K}) where Wi‚àà{1,‚Ä¶,2n‚ÄãRi}subscriptùëäùëñ1‚Ä¶superscript2ùëõsubscriptùëÖùëñW_{i}\in\{1,\ldots,2^{nR_{i}}\}, i=1,2,‚Ä¶,Kùëñ12‚Ä¶ùêæi=1,2,\ldots,K. The decoding functions at the receiver are W^i‚Äã(ùê≤in)subscript^ùëäùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùê≤ùëñùëõ\hat{W}_{i}(\mathbf{y}_{i}^{n}), i=1,2,‚Ä¶,Kùëñ12‚Ä¶ùêæi=1,2,\ldots,K. An error occurs when W^i‚â†Wisubscript^ùëäùëñsubscriptùëäùëñ\hat{W}_{i}\neq W_{i}. A rate vector ùêë=[R1,‚Ä¶,RK]TùêësuperscriptsubscriptùëÖ1‚Ä¶subscriptùëÖùêæùëá\mathbf{R}=[R_{1},\ldots,R_{K}]^{T} is said to be achievable if there exists a sequence of (n,2n‚ÄãR1,‚Ä¶,2n‚ÄãRK)MACsubscriptùëõsuperscript2ùëõsubscriptùëÖ1‚Ä¶superscript2ùëõsubscriptùëÖùêæMAC(n,2^{nR_{1}},\ldots,2^{nR_{K}})_{\mathrm{MAC}} codebooks for which the average probability of error Pe‚Üí0‚ÜísubscriptùëÉùëí0P_{e}\rightarrow 0 as the code length n‚Üí‚àû‚Üíùëõn\rightarrow\infty. The capacity region of a multiple access channel, denoted by ùíûMACsubscriptùíûMAC\mathcal{C}_{\mathrm{MAC}} is defined as the union of all achievable rate vectors [3]. We call the Gaussian vector multiple access channel in the MIMO case as MIMO-MAC throughout the rest of this paper.

III-B Duality between MIMO-BC and MIMO-MAC

The dual MIMO-MAC of a MIMO-BC can be constructed by changing the receivers in the MIMO-BC into transmitters and changing the transmitter in the MIMO-BC into the receiver. The channel gain matrices in dual MIMO-MAC are the conjugate transpose of the channel gain matrices in MIMO-BC. The maximum sum power in the dual MIMO-MAC is the same maximum power level as in MIMO-BC. The relationship between a MIMO-BC and its dual MIMO-MAC is illustrated in Fig.¬†4. Similar to MIMO-BC, We denote the capacity region of the dual MIMO-MAC as ùíûMAC‚Äã(P,ùêá‚Ä†)subscriptùíûMACùëÉsuperscriptùêá‚Ä†\mathcal{C}_{\mathrm{MAC}}(P,\mathbf{H}^{{\dagger}}).

The following Lemma states the relationship between the capacity regions of a MIMO-BC and its dual MIMO-MAC.

Lemma 1

The DPC region of a MIMO-BC channel with maximum power constraint PùëÉP is equal to the capacity region of the dual MIMO MAC with sum power constraint PùëÉP

ùíûDPC‚Äã(P,ùêá)=ùíûMAC‚Äã(P,ùêá‚Ä†).subscriptùíûDPCùëÉùêásubscriptùíûMACùëÉsuperscriptùêá‚Ä†\mathcal{C}_{\mathrm{DPC}}(P,\mathbf{H})=\mathcal{C}_{\mathrm{MAC}}(P,\mathbf{H}^{{\dagger}}).
Proof:

The proof of this theorem can be arrived in various ways [8, 9, 10]. The most straightforward approach is to show that any MIMO-BC achievable rate vector is also achievable in its dual MIMO-MAC and vice versa. The MAC-to-BC and BC-to-MAC mappings can be found in [8]. It is also shown in [8] that any rate vector in a MIMO-BC with a particular encoding order can be achieved in its dual MIMO-MAC with the reversed successive decoding order. ‚àé

III-C Convexity of MIMO-MAC Capacity Region

From Lemma¬†1, we know that the capacity region of a MIMO-BC and its dual MIMO-MAC is exactly the same. Therefore, we can replace ùíûDPC‚Äã(‚ãÖ)subscriptùíûDPC‚ãÖ\mathcal{C}_{\mathrm{DPC}}(\cdot) in (9) by the capacity regions of the dual MIMO-MAC channels ùíûMAC‚Äã(‚ãÖ)subscriptùíûMAC‚ãÖ\mathcal{C}_{\mathrm{MAC}}(\cdot). The benefits of such replacements is due to the following theorem.

Theorem 1

The capacity region of a KùêæK-user MIMO-MAC channel with a sum power constraint ‚àëi=1KTr‚Äã(ùêêi)‚â§Pmaxsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùêæTrsubscriptùêêùëñsubscriptùëÉ\sum_{i=1}^{K}\mathrm{Tr}(\mathbf{Q}_{i})\leq P_{\max} is convex with respect to the input covariance matrices ùêê1,‚Ä¶,ùêêKsubscriptùêê1‚Ä¶subscriptùêêùêæ\mathbf{Q}_{1},\ldots,\mathbf{Q}_{K}.

Theorem 14.3.5 in [3] states that the capacity region of a MIMO-MAC is determined by

ùíûMAC‚Äã(ùêê1,‚Ä¶,ùêêK)=subscriptùíûMACsubscriptùêê1‚Ä¶subscriptùêêùêæabsent\displaystyle\mathcal{C}_{\mathrm{MAC}}(\mathbf{Q}_{1},\ldots,\mathbf{Q}_{K})= (14)

where the mutual information expression I(;)I(;) can be bounded as follows:

I(ùê±i,i‚ààùíÆ;ùê≤|ùê±i,i‚ààùíÆc)‚â§log|ùêà+‚àëi‚ààùíÆùêái‚Ä†ùêêiùêái|.I(\mathbf{x}_{i},{i\in\mathcal{S}};\mathbf{y}|\mathbf{x}_{i},{i\in\mathcal{S}^{c}})\leq\log\left|\mathbf{I}+\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}}\mathbf{H}_{i}^{{\dagger}}\mathbf{Q}_{i}\mathbf{H}_{i}\right|. (15)

To show that the capacity region of the MIMO-MAC with a sum power constraint is convex, it is equivalent to show that the convex hull operation in (14) is unnecessary. To show this, consider the convex combination of two arbitrarily chosen achievable rate vectors [R1,‚Ä¶,RK]subscriptùëÖ1‚Ä¶subscriptùëÖùêæ[R_{1},\ldots,R_{K}] and [R^1,‚Ä¶,R^K]subscript^ùëÖ1‚Ä¶subscript^ùëÖùêæ[\hat{R}_{1},\ldots,\hat{R}_{K}] determined by two feasible power vectors [ùêê1,‚Ä¶,ùêêK]subscriptùêê1‚Ä¶subscriptùêêùêæ[\mathbf{Q}_{1},\ldots,\mathbf{Q}_{K}] and [ùêê^1,‚Ä¶,ùêê^K]subscript^ùêê1‚Ä¶subscript^ùêêùêæ[\hat{\mathbf{Q}}_{1},\ldots,\hat{\mathbf{Q}}_{K}], respectively, i.e., we have ‚àëi=1KTr‚Äã(ùêêi)‚â§Pmaxsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùêæTrsubscriptùêêùëñsubscriptùëÉ\sum_{i=1}^{K}\mathrm{Tr}(\mathbf{Q}_{i})\leq P_{\max} and ‚àëi=1KTr‚Äã(ùêê^i)‚â§Pmaxsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùêæTrsubscript^ùêêùëñsubscriptùëÉ\sum_{i=1}^{K}\mathrm{Tr}(\hat{\mathbf{Q}}_{i})\leq P_{\max}. Let 0‚â§Œ±‚â§10ùõº10\leq\alpha\leq 1 and consider the convex combination

[R¬Ø1,‚Ä¶,R¬ØK]=Œ±‚Äã[R1,‚Ä¶,RK]+(1‚àíŒ±)‚Äã[R^1,‚Ä¶,R^K].subscript¬ØùëÖ1‚Ä¶subscript¬ØùëÖùêæùõºsubscriptùëÖ1‚Ä¶subscriptùëÖùêæ1ùõºsubscript^ùëÖ1‚Ä¶subscript^ùëÖùêæ[\bar{R}_{1},\ldots,\bar{R}_{K}]=\alpha[R_{1},\ldots,R_{K}]+(1-\alpha)[\hat{R}_{1},\ldots,\hat{R}_{K}].

Also, let ùêê¬Øi=Œ±‚Äãùêêi+(1‚àíŒ±)‚Äãùêê^isubscript¬Øùêêùëñùõºsubscriptùêêùëñ1ùõºsubscript^ùêêùëñ\bar{\mathbf{Q}}_{i}=\alpha\mathbf{Q}_{i}+(1-\alpha)\hat{\mathbf{Q}}_{i}, i=1,‚Ä¶,Kùëñ1‚Ä¶ùêæi=1,\ldots,K. Now, consider

III-D Maximum Weighted Sum Rate Problem of the Dual MIMO-MAC

Now, we consider the maximum weighted sum rate problem of the dual MIMO-MAC. We simplify this problem such that we do not have to enumerate all possible successive decoding order in the dual MIMO-MAC, thus paving the way to efficiently solve the link layer subproblem we discuss in Section¬†IV.

It then follows that the maximum weighted sum rate problem of MIMO-MAC is equivalent to maximizing (III-D) subject to the sum power constraint, i.e., the optimization problem in (16). After solving CRPA-E, we can recover the corresponding MIMO-BC covariance matrices ùö™‚àósuperscriptùö™\mathbf{\Gamma}^{*} from the optimal solution ùêê‚àósuperscriptùêê\mathbf{Q}^{*} of CRPA-E by the MAC-to-BC mapping provided in [8].

IV Solution Procedure

Since CRPA-E is a convex programming problem, we can solve CRPA-E exactly by solving its Lagrangian dual problem. Introducing Lagrangian multipliers uisubscriptùë¢ùëñu_{i} to the link capacity coupling constraints ‚ü®ùüè,ùêìT‚Äãùêûl‚ü©‚â§Rl‚Äã(ùêê)1superscriptùêìùëásubscriptùêûùëôsubscriptùëÖùëôùêê\langle\mathbf{1},\mathbf{T}^{T}\mathbf{e}_{l}\rangle\leq R_{l}(\mathbf{Q}), Hence, we can write the Lagrangian as

Œò‚Äã(ùêÆ)=supùêí,ùêì,ùêê{L‚Äã(ùêí,ùêì,ùêê,ùêÆ)|(ùêí,ùêì,ùêê)‚ààŒ®},ŒòùêÆsubscriptsupremumùêíùêìùêêconditional-setùêøùêíùêìùêêùêÆùêíùêìùêêŒ®\Theta(\mathbf{u})=\sup_{\mathbf{S},\mathbf{T},\mathbf{Q}}\left\{L(\mathbf{S},\mathbf{T},\mathbf{Q},\mathbf{u})|(\mathbf{S},\mathbf{T},\mathbf{Q})\in\Psi\right\}, (24)

where

L‚Äã(ùêí,ùêì,ùêê,ùêÆ)=‚àëfln‚Å°(sf)+‚àëlul‚Äã(Rl‚Äã(ùêê)‚àí‚ü®ùüè,ùêìT‚Äãùêûl‚ü©)ùêøùêíùêìùêêùêÆsubscriptùëìsubscriptùë†ùëìsubscriptùëôsubscriptùë¢ùëôsubscriptùëÖùëôùêê1superscriptùêìùëásubscriptùêûùëôL(\mathbf{S},\mathbf{T},\mathbf{Q},\mathbf{u})=\sum_{f}\ln\left(s_{f}\right)+\sum_{l}u_{l}\left(R_{l}(\mathbf{Q})-\langle\mathbf{1},\mathbf{T}^{T}\mathbf{e}_{l}\rangle\right)

and Œ®Œ®\Psi is defined as

Œ®‚âú{(ùêí,ùêì,ùêê)|ùêÄùêì=ùêíùêì‚â•ùüéùêíùêûf=src‚Äã(f),dst‚Äã(f)ùüé‚àÄf‚ü®ùüè,ùêíùêûf‚ü©=0‚àÄf(ùêíùêûf)src‚Äã(f)=sf‚àÄf‚àël‚ààùí™‚Äã(n)Tr‚Äã{ùêêl}‚â§Pmax(n)‚àÄnùêêl‚™∞0‚àÄlRl‚Äã(ùêê)‚ààùíûMAC‚Äã(Pmax(n),ùêá‚Ä†(n))‚àÄn}.{\small\Psi\triangleq\left\{(\mathbf{S},\mathbf{T},\mathbf{Q})\left|\begin{array}[]{ll}\mathbf{A}\mathbf{T}=\mathbf{S}\\ \mathbf{T}\geq\mathbf{0}\\ \mathbf{S}\mathbf{e}_{f}=_{\mathrm{src}(f),\mathrm{dst}(f)}\mathbf{0}&\forall\,f\\ \langle\mathbf{1},\mathbf{S}\mathbf{e}_{f}\rangle=0&\forall\,f\\ (\mathbf{S}\mathbf{e}_{f})_{\mathrm{src}(f)}=s_{f}&\forall\,f\\ \sum_{l\in\mathcal{O}\left(n\right)}\mathrm{Tr}\{\mathbf{Q}_{l}\}\leq P_{\max}^{(n)}&\forall\,n\\ \mathbf{Q}_{l}\succeq 0&\forall\,l\\ R_{l}(\mathbf{Q})\in\mathcal{C}_{\mathrm{MAC}}(P_{\max}^{(n)},\mathbf{H}^{{\dagger}(n)})&\forall\,n\\ \end{array}\right.\right\}}.

The Lagrangian dual problem of CRPA can thus be written as:

ùêÉCRPA‚àíE:MinimizeŒò‚Äã(ùêÆ)subject toùêÆ‚â•ùüé.\begin{array}[]{rll}\mathbf{D}^{\mathrm{CRPA-E}}:\quad\mbox{Minimize}&\Theta(\mathbf{u})&\\ \mbox{subject to}&\mathbf{u}\geq\mathbf{0}.\\ \end{array}

It is easy to recognize that, for a given ùêÆùêÆ\mathbf{u}, the Lagrangian in (24) can be rearranged and separated into two terms:

Œò‚Äã(ùêÆ)=Œònet‚Äã(ùêÆ)+Œòlink‚Äã(ùêÆ),ŒòùêÆsubscriptŒònetùêÆsubscriptŒòlinkùêÆ\Theta(\mathbf{u})=\Theta_{\mathrm{net}}(\mathbf{u})+\Theta_{\mathrm{link}}(\mathbf{u}),

The CRPA-E Lagrangian dual problem can thus be written as the following master dual problem:

ùêåùêÉCRPA‚àíE:MinimizeŒònet‚Äã(ùêÆ)+Œòlink‚Äã(ùêÆ)subject toùêÆ‚â•ùüé\begin{array}[]{rll}\mathbf{MD}^{\mathrm{CRPA-E}}:\quad\mbox{Minimize}&\Theta_{\mathrm{net}}(\mathbf{u})+\Theta_{\mathrm{link}}(\mathbf{u})&\\ \mbox{subject to}&\mathbf{u}\geq\mathbf{0}\\ \end{array}

Notice that Œòlink‚Äã(ùêÆ)subscriptŒòlinkùêÆ\Theta_{\mathrm{link}}(\mathbf{u}) can be further decomposed on a node-by-node basis as follows:

Œòlink‚Äã(ùêÆ)=max‚Äã‚àëlul‚ÄãRl‚Äã(ùêê)subscriptŒòlinkùêÆsubscriptùëôsubscriptùë¢ùëôsubscriptùëÖùëôùêê\displaystyle\Theta_{\mathrm{link}}(\mathbf{u})=\max\sum_{l}u_{l}R_{l}(\mathbf{Q})
=‚àën=1N(max‚Äã‚àël‚ààùí™‚Äã(n)ul‚ÄãRl‚Äã(ùêê))=‚àën=1NŒòlink(n)‚Äã(ùêÆ(n)).absentsuperscriptsubscriptùëõ1ùëÅsubscriptùëôùí™ùëõsubscriptùë¢ùëôsubscriptùëÖùëôùêêsuperscriptsubscriptùëõ1ùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptŒòlinkùëõsuperscriptùêÆùëõ\displaystyle=\sum_{n=1}^{N}\left(\max\sum_{l\in\mathcal{O}\left(n\right)}u_{l}R_{l}(\mathbf{Q})\right)=\sum_{n=1}^{N}\Theta_{\mathrm{link}}^{(n)}(\mathbf{u}^{(n)}). (27)

It is seen that Œòlink(n)‚Äã(ùêÆ(n))‚âúmax‚Äã‚àël‚ààùí™‚Äã(n)ul‚ÄãRl‚Äã(ùêê)‚âúsuperscriptsubscriptŒòlinkùëõsuperscriptùêÆùëõsubscriptùëôùí™ùëõsubscriptùë¢ùëôsubscriptùëÖùëôùêê\Theta_{\mathrm{link}}^{(n)}(\mathbf{u}^{(n)})\triangleq\max\sum_{l\in\mathcal{O}\left(n\right)}u_{l}R_{l}(\mathbf{Q}) is a maximum weighted sum rate problem of the dual MIMO-MAC for some given dual variables ùêÆ(n)superscriptùêÆùëõ\mathbf{u}^{(n)} as weights. Without loss of generality, suppose that node nùëõn has KùêæK outgoing links, which are indexed as 1,‚Ä¶,K1‚Ä¶ùêæ1,\ldots,K and are associated with dual variables u1,‚Ä¶,uKsubscriptùë¢1‚Ä¶subscriptùë¢ùêæu_{1},\ldots,u_{K}, respectively. Let œÄ‚Äã(i)‚àà{1,‚Ä¶,K}ùúãùëñ1‚Ä¶ùêæ\pi(i)\in\{1,\ldots,K\} be the permutation such that 0‚â§uœÄ‚Äã(1)‚â§‚Ä¶‚â§uœÄ‚Äã(K)0subscriptùë¢ùúã1‚Ä¶subscriptùë¢ùúãùêæ0\leq u_{\pi(1)}\leq\ldots\leq u_{\pi(K)} and define uœÄ‚Äã(0)=0subscriptùë¢ùúã00u_{\pi(0)}=0. Œòlink(n)‚Äã(ùêÆ(n))superscriptsubscriptŒòlinkùëõsuperscriptùêÆùëõ\Theta_{\mathrm{link}}^{(n)}(\mathbf{u}^{(n)}) can be written as follows:

Maximize‚àëi=1K(uœÄ‚Äã(i)‚àíuœÄ‚Äã(i‚àí1))√ólog‚Å°|ùêà+‚àëj=iKœÅœÄ‚Äã(j)‚ÄãùêáœÄ‚Äã(j)‚Ä†‚ÄãùêêœÄ‚Äã(j)‚ÄãùêáœÄ‚Äã(j)|subject to‚àëi=1KTr‚Äã(ùêêi)‚â§Pmax(n)ùêêi‚™∞0,i=1,‚Ä¶,K.\begin{array}[]{rl}\mbox{Maximize}&\!\!\!\sum_{i=1}^{K}(u_{\pi(i)}-u_{\pi(i-1)})\times\\ &\!\!\!\log\left|\mathbf{I}+\sum_{j=i}^{K}\rho_{\pi(j)}\mathbf{H}_{\pi(j)}^{{\dagger}}\mathbf{Q}_{\pi(j)}\mathbf{H}_{\pi(j)}\right|\\ \mbox{subject to}&\!\!\!\sum_{i=1}^{K}\mathrm{Tr}(\mathbf{Q}_{i})\leq P_{\max}^{(n)}\\ &\!\!\!\mathbf{Q}_{i}\succeq 0,\,\,i=1,\ldots,K.\end{array} (28)

Note that in the network layer subproblem Œònet‚Äã(ùêÆ)subscriptŒònetùêÆ\Theta_{\mathrm{net}}(\mathbf{u}), the objective function is concave and all constraints are affine. Therefore, Œònet‚Äã(ùêÆ)subscriptŒònetùêÆ\Theta_{\mathrm{net}}(\mathbf{u}) is readily solvable by many polynomial time convex programming methods. However, even though Œòlink(n)‚Äã(ùêÆ(n))superscriptsubscriptŒòlinkùëõsuperscriptùêÆùëõ\Theta_{\mathrm{link}}^{(n)}(\mathbf{u}^{(n)}) is also a convex problem, generic convex programming methods are not efficient because the structures of its objective function and constraints are very complex. In the following subsections, we will discuss in detail how to solve Œòlink(n)‚Äã(ùêÆ(n))superscriptsubscriptŒòlinkùëõsuperscriptùêÆùëõ\Theta_{\mathrm{link}}^{(n)}(\mathbf{u}^{(n)}).

IV-A Conjugate Gradient Projection for Solving Œòlink(n)‚Äã(ùêÆ(n))superscriptsubscriptŒòlinkùëõsuperscriptùêÆùëõ\Theta_{\mathrm{link}}^{(n)}(\mathbf{u}^{(n)})

We propose an efficient algorithm based on conjugate gradient projection (CGP) to solve (28). CGP utilizes the important and powerful concept of Hessian conjugacy to deflect the gradient direction appropriately so as to achieve the superlinear convergence rate [11], which is similar to that of the well-known quasi-Newton methods (e.g., BFGS method). In each iteration, CGP projects the conjugate gradient direction to find an improving feasible direction. The framework of CGP for solving (28) is shown in Algorithm¬†1.

We adopt the ‚ÄúArmijo‚Äôs Rule‚Äù inexact line search method to avoid excessive objective function evaluations, while still enjoying provable convergence [11]. For convenience, we use F‚Äã(ùêê)ùêπùêêF(\mathbf{Q}) to represent the objective function in (28), where ùêê=(ùêê1,‚Ä¶,ùêêK)ùêêsubscriptùêê1‚Ä¶subscriptùêêùêæ\mathbf{Q}=(\mathbf{Q}_{1},\ldots,\mathbf{Q}_{K}) denotes the set of covariance matrices at a node. According to Armijo‚Äôs Rule, in the kt‚Äãhsuperscriptùëòùë°‚Ñék^{th} iteration, we choose œÉk=1subscriptùúéùëò1\sigma_{k}=1 and Œ±k=Œ≤mksubscriptùõºùëòsuperscriptùõΩsubscriptùëöùëò\alpha_{k}=\beta^{m_{k}} (the same as in [12]), where mksubscriptùëöùëòm_{k} is the first non-negative integer mùëöm that satisfies

F‚Äã(ùêê(k+1))‚àíF‚Äã(ùêê(k))‚â•œÉ‚ÄãŒ≤m‚Äã‚ü®ùêÜ(k),ùêê¬Ø(k)‚àíùêê(k)‚ü©ùêπsuperscriptùêêùëò1ùêπsuperscriptùêêùëòùúésuperscriptùõΩùëösuperscriptùêÜùëòsuperscript¬Øùêêùëòsuperscriptùêêùëò\displaystyle F(\mathbf{Q}^{(k+1)})-F(\mathbf{Q}^{(k)})\geq\sigma\beta^{m}\langle\mathbf{G}^{(k)},\bar{\mathbf{Q}}^{(k)}-\mathbf{Q}^{(k)}\rangle
=œÉ‚ÄãŒ≤m‚Äã‚àëi=1KTr‚Äã[ùêÜi‚Ä†(k)‚Äã(ùêê¬Øi(k)‚àíùêêi(k))],absentùúésuperscriptùõΩùëösuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùêæTrdelimited-[]superscriptsubscriptùêÜùëñ‚Ä†absentùëòsuperscriptsubscript¬Øùêêùëñùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùêêùëñùëò\displaystyle=\sigma\beta^{m}\sum_{i=1}^{K}\mathrm{Tr}\left[\mathbf{G}_{i}^{{\dagger}(k)}\left(\bar{\mathbf{Q}}_{i}^{(k)}-\mathbf{Q}_{i}^{(k)}\right)\right], (29)

where 0<Œ≤<10ùõΩ10<\beta<1 and 0<œÉ<10ùúé10<\sigma<1 are fixed scalars.

IV-B Computing the Conjugate Gradients

By using the formula ‚àÇln‚Å°|ùêÄ+ùêÅùêóùêÇ|‚àÇùêó=[ùêÇ‚Äã(ùêÄ+ùêÅùêóùêÇ)‚àí1‚ÄãùêÅ]TùêÄùêÅùêóùêÇùêósuperscriptdelimited-[]ùêÇsuperscriptùêÄùêÅùêóùêÇ1ùêÅùëá\frac{\partial\ln\left|\mathbf{A}+\mathbf{B}\mathbf{X}\mathbf{C}\right|}{\partial\mathbf{X}}=\left[\mathbf{C}(\mathbf{A}+\mathbf{B}\mathbf{X}\mathbf{C})^{-1}\mathbf{B}\right]^{T} [12, 13], we can compute the partial derivative of the it‚Äãhsuperscriptùëñùë°‚Ñéi^{th} term in the summation of F‚Äã(ùêê)ùêπùêêF(\mathbf{Q}) with respect to ùêêœÄ‚Äã(j)subscriptùêêùúãùëó\mathbf{Q}_{\pi(j)}, j‚â•iùëóùëñj\geq i, as follows:

To compute the gradient of F‚Äã(ùêê)ùêπùêêF(\mathbf{Q}) with respect to ùêêœÄ‚Äã(j)subscriptùêêùúãùëó\mathbf{Q}_{\pi(j)}, we notice that only the first jùëój terms in F‚Äã(ùêê)ùêπùêêF(\mathbf{Q}) involve ùêêœÄ‚Äã(j)subscriptùêêùúãùëó\mathbf{Q}_{\pi(j)}. From the definition ‚àázf‚Äã(z)=2‚Äã(‚àÇf‚Äã(z)/‚àÇz)‚àósubscript‚àáùëßùëìùëß2superscriptùëìùëßùëß\nabla_{z}f(z)=2(\partial f(z)/\partial z)^{*} [14], we have

(ùêà+‚àëk=iKœÅœÄ‚Äã(k)ùêáœÄ‚Äã(k)‚Ä†ùêêœÄ‚Äã(k)ùêáœÄ‚Äã(k))‚àí1]ùêáœÄ‚Äã(j)‚Ä†.\displaystyle\left.\left(\mathbf{I}+\sum_{k=i}^{K}\rho_{\pi(k)}\mathbf{H}_{\pi(k)}^{{\dagger}}\mathbf{Q}_{\pi(k)}\mathbf{H}_{\pi(k)}\right)^{-1}\right]\mathbf{H}_{\pi(j)}^{{\dagger}}. (30)
Remark 1

It is important to point out that we can exploit the special structure in (IV-B) to significantly reduce the computation complexity in the implementation of the algorithm. Note that the most difficult part in computing ùêÜ¬ØœÄ‚Äã(j)subscript¬ØùêÜùúãùëó\bar{\mathbf{G}}_{\pi(j)} is the summation of the terms in the form of ùêáœÄ‚Äã(k)‚Ä†‚ÄãùêêœÄ‚Äã(k)‚ÄãùêáœÄ‚Äã(k)superscriptsubscriptùêáùúãùëò‚Ä†subscriptùêêùúãùëòsubscriptùêáùúãùëò\mathbf{H}_{\pi(k)}^{{\dagger}}\mathbf{Q}_{\pi(k)}\mathbf{H}_{\pi(k)}. Without careful consideration, one may end up computing such additions j‚Äã(2‚ÄãK+1‚àíj)/2ùëó2ùêæ1ùëó2j(2K+1-j)/2 times for ùêÜ¬ØœÄ‚Äã(j)subscript¬ØùêÜùúãùëó\bar{\mathbf{G}}_{\pi(j)}. However, notice that when jùëój varies, most of the terms in the summation are still the same. Thus, we can maintain a running sum for ùêà+‚àëk=iKœÅœÄ‚Äã(k)‚ÄãùêáœÄ‚Äã(k)‚Ä†‚ÄãùêêœÄ‚Äã(k)‚ÄãùêáœÄ‚Äã(k)ùêàsuperscriptsubscriptùëòùëñùêæsubscriptùúåùúãùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùêáùúãùëò‚Ä†subscriptùêêùúãùëòsubscriptùêáùúãùëò\mathbf{I}+\sum_{k=i}^{K}\rho_{\pi(k)}\mathbf{H}_{\pi(k)}^{{\dagger}}\mathbf{Q}_{\pi(k)}\mathbf{H}_{\pi(k)}, start out from j=Kùëóùêæj=K, and reduce jùëój by one sequentially. As a result, only one new term is added to the running sum in each iteration, which means we only need to do the addition once in each iteration.

The conjugate gradient direction in the mt‚Äãhsuperscriptùëöùë°‚Ñém^{th} iteration can be computed as ùêÜœÄ‚Äã(j)(m)=ùêÜ¬ØœÄ‚Äã(i)(m)+Œ∫m‚ÄãùêÜœÄ‚Äã(i)(m‚àí1)superscriptsubscriptùêÜùúãùëóùëösuperscriptsubscript¬ØùêÜùúãùëñùëösubscriptùúÖùëösuperscriptsubscriptùêÜùúãùëñùëö1\mathbf{G}_{\pi(j)}^{(m)}=\bar{\mathbf{G}}_{\pi(i)}^{(m)}+\kappa_{m}\mathbf{G}_{\pi(i)}^{(m-1)}. We adopt the Fletcher and Reeves‚Äô choice of deflection [11], which can be computed as

Œ∫m=‚ÄñùêÜ¬ØœÄ‚Äã(j)(m)‚Äñ2‚ÄñùêÜ¬ØœÄ‚Äã(j)(m‚àí1)‚Äñ2.subscriptùúÖùëösuperscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript¬ØùêÜùúãùëóùëö2superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript¬ØùêÜùúãùëóùëö12\kappa_{m}=\frac{\|\bar{\mathbf{G}}_{\pi(j)}^{(m)}\|^{2}}{\|\bar{\mathbf{G}}_{\pi(j)}^{(m-1)}\|^{2}}. (31)

The purpose of deflecting the gradient using (31) is to find ùêÜœÄ‚Äã(j)(m)superscriptsubscriptùêÜùúãùëóùëö\mathbf{G}_{\pi(j)}^{(m)}, which is the Hessian-conjugate of ùêÜœÄ‚Äã(j)(m‚àí1)superscriptsubscriptùêÜùúãùëóùëö1\mathbf{G}_{\pi(j)}^{(m-1)}. By doing so, we can eliminate the ‚Äúzigzagging‚Äù phenomenon encountered in the conventional gradient projection method, and achieve the superlinear convergence rate [11] without actually storing a large Hessian approximation matrix as in quasi-Newton methods.

IV-C Projection onto Œ©+‚Äã(Pmax(n))subscriptŒ©superscriptsubscriptùëÉùëõ\Omega_{+}(P_{\max}^{(n)})

Noting from (IV-B) that ùêÜœÄ‚Äã(j)subscriptùêÜùúãùëó\mathbf{G}_{\pi(j)} is Hermitian, we have that ùêêœÄ‚Äã(j)(k)‚Ä≤=ùêêœÄ‚Äã(j)(k)+sk‚ÄãùêÜœÄ‚Äã(j)(k)\mathbf{Q}_{\pi(j)}^{{}^{\prime}(k)}=\mathbf{Q}_{\pi(j)}^{(k)}+s_{k}\mathbf{G}_{\pi(j)}^{(k)} is Hermitian as well. Then, the projection problem becomes how to simultaneously project |ùí™‚Äã(n)|ùí™ùëõ|\mathcal{O}\left(n\right)| Hermitian matrices onto the set

Œ©+(Pmax(n))‚âú{ùêêl|‚àëlTr‚Äã{ùêêl}‚â§Pmax(n),ùêêl‚™∞0,l‚ààùí™‚Äã(n)}.\Omega_{+}(P_{\max}^{(n)})\triangleq\left\{\mathbf{Q}_{l}\left|\begin{array}[]{l}\sum_{l}\mathrm{Tr}\{\mathbf{Q}_{l}\}\leq P_{\max}^{(n)},\\ \mathbf{Q}_{l}\succeq 0,\,\,l\in\mathcal{O}\left(n\right)\end{array}\right.\right\}.

This problem belongs to the class of ‚Äúmatrix nearness problems‚Äù [15, 16], which are not easy to solve in general. However, by exploiting the special structure in Œòlink(n)‚Äã(ùêÆ)superscriptsubscriptŒòlinkùëõùêÆ\Theta_{\mathrm{link}}^{(n)}(\mathbf{u}), we are able to design a polynomial-time algorithm.

We construct a block diagonal matrix ùêÉ=Diag{ùêêœÄ‚Äã(1)‚Äã‚Ä¶‚ÄãùêêœÄ‚Äã(K)}‚àà‚ÑÇ(K‚ãÖnr)√ó(K‚ãÖnr)ùêÉDiag{ùêêœÄ(1)‚Ä¶ùêêœÄ(K)}superscript‚ÑÇ‚ãÖùêæsubscriptùëõùëü‚ãÖùêæsubscriptùëõùëü\mathbf{D}=\mbox{Diag}\mbox{$\left\{\mathbf{Q}_{\pi(1)}\ldots\mathbf{Q}_{\pi(K)}\right\}$}\in\mathbb{C}^{(K\cdot n_{r})\times(K\cdot n_{r})}. It is easy to recognize that ùêêœÄ‚Äã(j)‚ààŒ©+‚Äã(Pmax(n))subscriptùêêùúãùëósubscriptŒ©superscriptsubscriptùëÉùëõ\mathbf{Q}_{\pi(j)}\in\Omega_{+}(P_{\max}^{(n)}), j=1,‚Ä¶,Kùëó1‚Ä¶ùêæj=1,\ldots,K, only if Tr‚Äã(ùêÉ)=‚àëj=1KTr‚Äã(ùêêœÄ‚Äã(j))‚â§Pmax(n)TrùêÉsuperscriptsubscriptùëó1ùêæTrsubscriptùêêùúãùëósuperscriptsubscriptùëÉùëõ\mathrm{Tr}(\mathbf{D})=\sum_{j=1}^{K}\mathrm{Tr}\left(\mathbf{Q}_{\pi(j)}\right)\leq P_{\max}^{(n)} and ùêÉ‚™∞0succeeds-or-equalsùêÉ0\mathbf{D}\succeq 0. We use Frobenius norm, denoted by ‚à•‚ãÖ‚à•F\|\cdot\|_{F}, as the matrix distance criterion. The distance between two matrices ùêÄùêÄ\mathbf{A} and ùêÅùêÅ\mathbf{B} is defined as ‚ÄñùêÄ‚àíùêÅ‚ÄñF=(Tr‚Äã[(ùêÄ‚àíùêÅ)‚Ä†‚Äã(ùêÄ‚àíùêÅ)])12subscriptnormùêÄùêÅùêπsuperscriptTrdelimited-[]superscriptùêÄùêÅ‚Ä†ùêÄùêÅ12\|\mathbf{A}-\mathbf{B}\|_{F}=\left(\mathrm{Tr}\left[(\mathbf{A}-\mathbf{B})^{{\dagger}}(\mathbf{A}-\mathbf{B})\right]\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}. Thus, given a block diagonal matrix ùêÉùêÉ\mathbf{D}, we wish to find a matrix ùêÉ~‚ààŒ©+‚Äã(Pmax(n))~ùêÉsubscriptŒ©superscriptsubscriptùëÉùëõ\tilde{\mathbf{D}}\in\Omega_{+}(P_{\max}^{(n)}) such that ùêÉ~~ùêÉ\tilde{\mathbf{D}} minimizes ‚ÄñùêÉ~‚àíùêÉ‚ÄñFsubscriptnorm~ùêÉùêÉùêπ\|\tilde{\mathbf{D}}-\mathbf{D}\|_{F}. For more convenient algebraic manipulations, we instead study the following equivalent optimization problem:

Minimize12‚Äã‚ÄñùêÉ~‚àíùêÉ‚ÄñF2subject toTr‚Äã(ùêÉ~)‚â§Pmax(n),ùêÉ~‚™∞0.Minimize12superscriptsubscriptnorm~ùêÉùêÉùêπ2subject toformulae-sequenceTr~ùêÉsuperscriptsubscriptùëÉùëõsucceeds-or-equals~ùêÉ0\begin{array}[]{rl}\mbox{Minimize}&\frac{1}{2}\|\tilde{\mathbf{D}}-\mathbf{D}\|_{F}^{2}\\ \mbox{subject to}&\mathrm{Tr}(\tilde{\mathbf{D}})\leq P_{\max}^{(n)},\,\,\tilde{\mathbf{D}}\succeq 0.\\ \end{array} (32)

In (32), the objective function is convex in ùêÉ~~ùêÉ\tilde{\mathbf{D}}, the constraint ùêÉ~‚™∞0succeeds-or-equals~ùêÉ0\tilde{\mathbf{D}}\succeq 0 represents the convex cone of positive semidefinite matrices, and the constraint Tr‚Äã(ùêÉ~)‚â§Pmax(n)Tr~ùêÉsuperscriptsubscriptùëÉùëõ\mathrm{Tr}(\tilde{\mathbf{D}})\leq P_{\max}^{(n)} is a linear constraint. Thus, the problem is a convex minimization problem and we can exactly solve this problem by solving its Lagrangian dual problem. Associating Hermitian matrix ùö∑ùö∑\mathbf{\Pi} to the constraint ùêÉ~‚™∞0succeeds-or-equals~ùêÉ0\tilde{\mathbf{D}}\succeq 0 and Œºùúá\mu to the constraint Tr‚Äã(ùêÉ~)‚â§Pmax(n)Tr~ùêÉsuperscriptsubscriptùëÉùëõ\mathrm{Tr}(\tilde{\mathbf{D}})\leq P_{\max}^{(n)}, we can write the Lagrangian as g‚Äã(ùö∑,Œº)=minùêÉ~‚Å°{(1/2)‚Äã‚ÄñùêÉ~‚àíùêÉ‚ÄñF2‚àíTr‚Äã(ùö∑‚Ä†‚ÄãùêÉ~)+Œº‚Äã(Tr‚Äã(ùêÉ~)‚àíPmax(n))}ùëîùö∑ùúásubscript~ùêÉ12superscriptsubscriptnorm~ùêÉùêÉùêπ2Trsuperscriptùö∑‚Ä†~ùêÉùúáTr~ùêÉsuperscriptsubscriptùëÉùëõg(\mathbf{\Pi},\mu)=\min_{\tilde{\mathbf{D}}}\{(1/2)\|\tilde{\mathbf{D}}-\mathbf{D}\|_{F}^{2}-\mathrm{Tr}(\mathbf{\Pi}^{{\dagger}}\tilde{\mathbf{D}})+\mu(\mathrm{Tr}(\tilde{\mathbf{D}})-P_{\max}^{(n)})\}. Since g‚Äã(ùö∑,Œº)ùëîùö∑ùúág(\mathbf{\Pi},\mu) is an unconstrained convex quadratic minimization problem, we can compute the minimizer of the Lagrangian by simply setting its first derivative (with respect to ùêÉ~~ùêÉ\tilde{\mathbf{D}}) to zero, i.e., (ùêÉ~‚àíùêÉ)‚àíùö∑‚Ä†+Œº‚Äãùêà=0~ùêÉùêÉsuperscriptùö∑‚Ä†ùúáùêà0(\tilde{\mathbf{D}}-\mathbf{D})-\mathbf{\Pi}^{{\dagger}}+\mu\mathbf{I}=0. Noting that ùö∑‚Ä†=ùö∑superscriptùö∑‚Ä†ùö∑\mathbf{\Pi}^{{\dagger}}=\mathbf{\Pi}, we have ùêÉ~=ùêÉ‚àíŒº‚Äãùêà+ùö∑~ùêÉùêÉùúáùêàùö∑\tilde{\mathbf{D}}=\mathbf{D}-\mu\mathbf{I}+\mathbf{\Pi}. Substituting ùêÉ~~ùêÉ\tilde{\mathbf{D}} back into the Lagrangian, we have

IV-D Solving the Master Dual Problem

IV-D1 Cutting-Plane Method for Solving Œò‚Äã(ùêÆ)ŒòùêÆ\Theta(\mathbf{u})

The attractive feature of the cutting-plane method is its robustness, speed of convergence, and its simplicity in recovering primal feasible optimal solutions. The primal optimal feasible solution can be exactly computed by averaging all the primal solutions (may or may not be primal feasible) using the dual variables as weights [11]. Letting z=Œò‚Äã(ùêÆ)ùëßŒòùêÆz=\Theta(\mathbf{u}), the dual problem is equivalent to

Minimizezsubject toz‚â•‚àëfln‚Å°(sf)+‚àëlul‚Äã(Rl‚Äã(ùêê)‚àí‚ü®ùüè,ùêìT‚Äãùêûl‚ü©)ùêÆ‚â•0,Minimizeùëßsubject toùëßsubscriptùëìsubscriptùë†ùëìsubscriptùëôsubscriptùë¢ùëôsubscriptùëÖùëôùêê1superscriptùêìùëásubscriptùêûùëômissing-subexpressionùêÆ0\begin{array}[]{rl}\mbox{Minimize}&z\\ \mbox{subject to}&z\geq\sum_{f}\ln\left(s_{f}\right)+\sum_{l}u_{l}\left(R_{l}(\mathbf{Q})-\langle\mathbf{1},\mathbf{T}^{T}\mathbf{e}_{l}\rangle\right)\\ &\mathbf{u}\geq 0,\end{array} (37)

where (ùêí,ùêì,ùêê)‚ààŒ®ùêíùêìùêêŒ®(\mathbf{S},\mathbf{T},\mathbf{Q})\in\Psi. Although (37) is a linear program with infinite constraints not known explicitly, we can consider the following approximating problem:

Minimizezsubject toz‚â•‚àëfln(sf(j))+‚àëlul(Rl(ùêê(j))‚àí‚ü®ùüè,ùêì(j)‚ÄãTùêûl‚ü©)ùêÆ‚â•0,\begin{array}[]{rl}\mbox{Minimize}&z\\ \mbox{subject to}&z\geq\sum_{f}\ln(s_{f}^{(j)})+\sum_{l}u_{l}\left(R_{l}(\mathbf{Q}^{(j)})-\right.\\ &\quad\quad\left.\langle\mathbf{1},\mathbf{T}^{(j)T}\mathbf{e}_{l}\rangle\right)\!\!\!\\ &\mathbf{u}\geq 0,\end{array} (38)

where the points (ùêí(j),ùêì(j),ùêê(j))‚ààŒ®superscriptùêíùëósuperscriptùêìùëósuperscriptùêêùëóŒ®(\mathbf{S}^{(j)},\mathbf{T}^{(j)},\mathbf{Q}^{(j)})\in\Psi, j=1,‚Ä¶,k‚àí1ùëó1‚Ä¶ùëò1j=1,\ldots,k-1. The problem in (38) is a linear program with a finite number of constraints and can be solved efficiently. Let (z(k),ùêÆ(k))superscriptùëßùëòsuperscriptùêÆùëò(z^{(k)},\mathbf{u}^{(k)}) be an optimal solution to the approximating problem, which we refer to as the master program. If the solution is feasible to (37), then it is an optimal solution to the Lagrangian dual problem. To check the feasibility, we consider the following subproblem:

Maximize‚àëfln‚Å°(sf)+‚àëlul(k)‚Äã(Rl‚Äã(ùêê)‚àí‚ü®ùüè,ùêìT‚Äãùêûl‚ü©)subject to(ùêí,ùêì,ùêê)‚ààŒ®Maximizesubscriptùëìsubscriptùë†ùëìsubscriptùëôsuperscriptsubscriptùë¢ùëôùëòsubscriptùëÖùëôùêê1superscriptùêìùëásubscriptùêûùëôsubject toùêíùêìùêêŒ®\begin{array}[]{rl}\mbox{Maximize}&\sum_{f}\ln\left(s_{f}\right)+\sum_{l}u_{l}^{(k)}\left(R_{l}(\mathbf{Q})-\langle\mathbf{1},\mathbf{T}^{T}\mathbf{e}_{l}\rangle\right)\\ \mbox{subject to}&(\mathbf{S},\mathbf{T},\mathbf{Q})\in\Psi\end{array} (39)

Suppose that (ùêí(k),ùêì(k),ùêê(k))superscriptùêíùëòsuperscriptùêìùëòsuperscriptùêêùëò(\mathbf{S}^{(k)},\mathbf{T}^{(k)},\mathbf{Q}^{(k)}) is an optimal solution to the subproblem (39) and Œò‚àó‚Äã(ùêÆ(k))superscriptŒòsuperscriptùêÆùëò\Theta^{*}(\mathbf{u}^{(k)}) is the corresponding optimal objective value. If zk‚â•Œò‚àó‚Äã(ùêÆ(k))subscriptùëßùëòsuperscriptŒòsuperscriptùêÆùëòz_{k}\geq\Theta^{*}(\mathbf{u}^{(k)}), then ùêÆ(k)superscriptùêÆùëò\mathbf{u}^{(k)} is an optimal solution to the Lagrangian dual problem. Otherwise, for ùêÆ=ùêÆ(k)ùêÆsuperscriptùêÆùëò\mathbf{u}=\mathbf{u}^{(k)}, the inequality constraint in (37) is not satisfied for (ùêí(j),ùêì(j),ùêê(j))superscriptùêíùëósuperscriptùêìùëósuperscriptùêêùëó(\mathbf{S}^{(j)},\mathbf{T}^{(j)},\mathbf{Q}^{(j)}). Thus, we can add the constraint

to (38), and re-solve the master linear program. Obviously, (z(k),ùêÆ(k))superscriptùëßùëòsuperscriptùêÆùëò(z^{(k)},\mathbf{u}^{(k)}) violates (40) and will be cut off by (40). The cutting plane algorithm is summarized in Algorithm¬†3.

IV-D2 Subgradient Algorithm for Solving Œò‚Äã(ùêÆ)ŒòùêÆ\Theta(\mathbf{u})

Since the Lagrangian dual objective function is piece-wise differentiable, subgradient method can also be applied. For Œò‚Äã(ùêÆ)ŒòùêÆ\Theta(\mathbf{u}), starting with an initial ùêÆ(1)superscriptùêÆ1\mathbf{u}^{(1)} and after evaluating subproblems Œònet‚Äã(ùêÆ)subscriptŒònetùêÆ\Theta_{\mathrm{net}}(\mathbf{u}) and ŒòlinksubscriptŒòlink\Theta_{\mathrm{link}} for ùêÆ(k)superscriptùêÆùëò\mathbf{u}^{(k)} in the kt‚Äãhsuperscriptùëòùë°‚Ñék^{th} iteration, we update the dual variables by ùêÆ(k+1)=[ùêÆk‚àíŒª(k)‚Äãùêù(k)]+superscriptùêÆùëò1subscriptdelimited-[]superscriptùêÆùëòsubscriptùúÜùëòsuperscriptùêùùëò\mathbf{u}^{(k+1)}=\left[\mathbf{u}^{k}-\lambda_{(k)}\mathbf{d}^{(k)}\right]_{+}, where the operator [‚ãÖ]+subscriptdelimited-[]‚ãÖ[\cdot]_{+} projects a vector on to the nonnegative orthant, and ŒªksubscriptùúÜùëò\lambda_{k} denotes a positive scalar step size. ùêù(k)superscriptùêùùëò\mathbf{d}^{(k)} is a subgradient of the Lagrangian at point ùêÆ(k)superscriptùêÆùëò\mathbf{u}^{(k)}. It is proved in [11] that the subgradient algorithm converges if the step size ŒªksubscriptùúÜùëò\lambda_{k} satisfies Œªk‚Üí0‚ÜísubscriptùúÜùëò0\lambda_{k}\rightarrow 0 as k‚Üí‚àû‚Üíùëòk\rightarrow\infty and ‚àëk=0‚àûŒªk=‚àûsuperscriptsubscriptùëò0subscriptùúÜùëò\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\lambda_{k}=\infty. A simple and useful step size selection strategy is the divergent harmonic series ‚àëk=1‚àûŒ≤‚Äã1k=‚àûsuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùõΩ1ùëò\sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\beta\frac{1}{k}=\infty, where Œ≤ùõΩ\beta is a constant. The subgradient for the Lagrangian dual problem can be computed as

Rl‚Äã(ùêê‚àó‚Äã(ùêÆ))‚àí‚ü®ùüè,ùêì‚àó‚Äã(ùêÆ)T‚Äãùêûl‚ü©,l=1,2,‚Ä¶,L.formulae-sequencesubscriptùëÖùëôsuperscriptùêêùêÆ1superscriptùêìsuperscriptùêÆùëásubscriptùêûùëôùëô12‚Ä¶ùêøR_{l}(\mathbf{Q}^{*}(\mathbf{u}))-\langle\mathbf{1},\mathbf{T}^{*}(\mathbf{u})^{T}\mathbf{e}_{l}\rangle,\quad l=1,2,\ldots,L. (41)

Specifically, the subgradient method has the following properties which make it possible to be implemented in a distributed fashion:

  1. 1.

    Subgradient computation only requires local traffic information ‚ü®ùüè,ùêìT‚Äãùêûl‚ü©1superscriptùêìùëásubscriptùêûùëô\langle\mathbf{1},\mathbf{T}^{T}\mathbf{e}_{l}\rangle and the available link capacity information Rl‚Äã(ùêê)subscriptùëÖùëôùêêR_{l}(\mathbf{Q}) at each link lùëôl. As a result, it can be computed locally.

  2. 2.

    The choice of step size Œªk=Œ≤‚Äã1ksubscriptùúÜùëòùõΩ1ùëò\lambda_{k}=\beta\frac{1}{k} depends only upon the iteration index kùëòk, and does not require any other global knowledge. In conjunction with the first property, the dual variable, in the iterative form of ul(k+1)=ul(k)+Œªk‚Äã(‚àÇŒò‚Äã(ùêÆ)/‚àÇul)superscriptsubscriptùë¢ùëôùëò1superscriptsubscriptùë¢ùëôùëòsubscriptùúÜùëòŒòùêÆsubscriptùë¢ùëôu_{l}^{(k+1)}=u_{l}^{(k)}+\lambda_{k}(\partial\Theta(\mathbf{u})/\partial u_{l}), can also be computed locally.

  3. 3.

    The objective functions ŒòlinksubscriptŒòlink\Theta_{\mathrm{link}} can be decomposed on a node-by-node basis such that each node in the network can perform the computation in parallel. Likewise, the network layer subproblem ŒònetsubscriptŒònet\Theta_{\mathrm{net}} can be decomposed on a source-by-source basis such that each source node can perform the routing computation locally after receiving the dual variable information of each link in the network.

It is worth to point out that care must be taken when recovering the primal feasible optimal solution in the subgradient method. Generally, the primal variables in the dual optimal solution are not primal feasible unless the dual optimal solution happens to be the saddle point. Fortunately, since CRPA-E is convex, its primal feasible optimal solution can be exactly computed by solving a linear programming problem (see [11] for further details). However, such a recovery approach cannot be implemented in a distributed fashion. In this paper, we adopt a variant of Shor‚Äôs rule to recovery primal optimal feasible solution. Due to space limitation, we refer readers to [18] for more details.

V Numerical Results

In this section, we present some numerical results through simulations to provide further insights on solving CRPA. NùëÅN randomly-generated MIMO-enabled nodes are uniformly distributed in a square region. Each node in the network is equipped with two antennas. The maximum transmit power for each node is set to Pmax=10subscriptùëÉ10P_{\max}=10dBm. Each node in the network is assigned a unit bandwidth. We illustrate a 15-node network example, as shown in Fig.¬†5, to show the convergence process of the cutting-plane and the subgradient methods for solving ùêÉCRPA‚àíEsuperscriptùêÉCRPAE\mathbf{D}^{\mathrm{CRPA-E}}. In this example, there are three flows transmitting across the network: N14 to N1, N6 to N10, and N5 to N4, respectively.

V-A Cutting-Plane Method

For the 15-node example in Fig.¬†5, the convergence process for the cutting-plane method is illustrated in Fig.¬†6.

The optimal objective value for this 15-node example is 6.72. The optimal flows for sessions N14 to N1, N6 to N10, and N5 to N4 are 9.179.179.17 bps/Hz, 9.309.309.30 bps/Hz, and 9.939.939.93 bps/Hz, respectively. It can be observed that the cutting-plane algorithm is very efficient: It converges with approximately 160 cuts. As expected, the duality gap is zero because the convexity of the transformed equivalent problem based on dual MIMO-MAC.

V-B Subgradient Method

For the 15-node example in Fig.¬†5, the convergence process for the subgradient method is illustrated in Fig.¬†7.

The step size selection is Œªk=0.1/ksubscriptùúÜùëò0.1ùëò\lambda_{k}=0.1/k. The subgradient method also achieves the same optimal solution and objective value when it converges. However, it is seen that the subgradient algorithm takes approximately 1600 iterations to converge, which is much slower than the cutting-plane method. This is partially due to the heuristic nature in step size selection (cannot be too large or too small at each step). It is also partially due to the cumbersomeness in recovering the primal feasible solution in the subgradient method. In this example, the dual upper bound takes approximately 1050 iterations to reach near the optimal. However, the near-optimal primal feasible solution cannot be identified until after 1500 iterations.

V-C Comparison between BC and TDM

We now study how much performance gain we can get by using Gaussian vector broadcast channel technique as opposed to the conventional time-division (TDM) scheme. The cross-layer optimization problem of MIMO-based mesh networks over TDM scheme is also a convex problem. Thus, the basic Lagrangian dual decomposition framework and gradient projection technique for the link layer subproblem are still applicable. The only difference is in the gradient computation, which is simpler in TDM case. For the same 15-node network with TDM, we plot the convergence process of the cutting-plane algorithm in Fig.¬†8.

In TDM case, the optimal objective value is 5.01. For this example, we have 34.4%percent34.434.4\% improvement by using DPC.

VI Related Work

Despite significant research progress in using MIMO for single-user communications, research on multi-user multi-hop MIMO networks is still in its inception stage. There are many open problems, and many areas are still poorly understood [19]. Currently, the relatively well-studied research area of multi-user MIMO systems are cellular systems, which are single-hop and infrastructure-based. For multi-hop MIMO-based mesh networks, research results remain limited. In [20], Hu and Zhang studied the problem of joint medium access control and routing, with a consideration of optimal hop distance to minimize end-to-end delay. In [21], Sundaresan and Sivakumar used simulations to study various characteristics and tradeoffs (multiplexing gain vs. diversity gain) of MIMO links that can be leveraged by routing layer protocols in rich multipath environments to improve performance. In [22], Lee et al. proposed a distributed algorithm for MIMO-based multi-hop ad hoc networks, in which diversity and multiplexing gains of each link are controlled to achieve the optimal rate-reliability tradeoff. The optimization problem assumes fixed SINRs and fixed routes between source and destination nodes. However, in these works, there is no explicit consideration of per-antenna power allocation and their impact on upper layers. Moreover, DPC in cross-layer design has never been studied either.

VII Conclusions

In this paper, we investigated the cross-layer optimization of DPC per-antenna power allocation and multi-hop multi-path routing for MIMO-based wireless mesh networks. Our contributions are three-fold. First, this paper is the first work that studies the impacts of applying dirty paper coding, which is the optimal transmission scheme for MIMO broadcast channels (MIMO-BC), to the cross-layer design for MIMO-based wireless mesh networks. We showed that the network performance has dramatic improvements compared to that of the conventional time-division/frequency division schemes. Second, we solved the challenging non-connvex cross-layer optimization problem by exploiting the channel duality between MIMO-MAC and MIMO-BC, and we showed that transformed problem under dual MIMO-MAC is convex. We simplified the maximum weighted sum rate problem, thus paving the way for solving the link layer subproblem in the Lagrangian dual decomposition. Last, for the transformed problem, we develop an efficient solution procedure that integrates Lagrangian dual decomposition, conjugate gradient projection based on matrix differential calculus, cutting-plane, and subgradient methods. Our results substantiate the importance of cross-layer optimization for MIMO-based wireless mesh networks with Gaussian vector broadcast channels.
